concern: Anyone have any tips for getting over bouts of insomnia related to school stress? I’m enrolled in 18 hours and as a senior have a lot of (seemingly) huge decisions coming up about post grad etc. I just can’t seem to get my thoughts under control and can no longer sleep more than 5 hours no matter how much I tire myself out…tired of feeling like a walking zombie.

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! Its great to chat with you. How are you feeling today? Is there anything specific youd like to talk about?
I'm feeling pretty exhausted today due to my ongoing sleep struggles. I'd like to talk about strategies for managing school-related stress to help improve my sleep.

It sounds like you're feeling worn out and looking for some strategies to manage stress and improve your sleep. School can be a major source of stress, so its understandable that youre feeling overwhelmed. Have you tried any relaxation techniques or sleep habits before?
Yes, I've tried tiring myself out through physical activities as a sleep habit. However, it hasn't been effective in managing my thoughts and improving my rest.

It can be frustrating when our efforts don't yield the desired results. It seems like you've recognized that managing your thoughts might be an important aspect of improving your rest. Have you considered any techniques that specifically focus on managing your thoughts, such as mindfulness or journaling?
I've considered mindfulness as a way to manage my racing thoughts, but I haven't tried it consistently yet. I'm interested in exploring journaling too, hoping it might help calm my mind before bed.

It's great that you're open to trying out mindfulness and journaling as strategies to manage your thoughts. Mindfulness can be a powerful tool to bring awareness to your thoughts and emotions, while journaling can help you process and release them. Would you like to discuss some ways you could incorporate these practices into your daily routine?
Yes, I'd like to discuss ways to incorporate mindfulness and journaling into my routine. I'm hoping these can help me quiet my mind and improve my sleep amidst my busy schedule.

Let's start by finding small, manageable ways to introduce mindfulness and journaling into your daily routine. One suggestion could be setting aside just 10 minutes each day, perhaps before bed, to practice a mindfulness exercise or write in your journal. Would you be able to commit to this small amount of time each day?

Yes, I think I can commit to setting aside 10 minutes each day, especially if it helps quiet my mind at bedtime. I'm hopeful this routine will make a difference in managing my stress and getting better sleep.

Great! To make it easier to stick to this new routine, let's identify a specific time and place for your daily mindfulness or journaling practice. Would you prefer to do it in your bedroom, a quiet corner of your home, or somewhere else? And would you like to set a reminder, perhaps on your phone, to help you remember?

I think my bedroom would be the best spot for this practice, as it's already a quiet space right before bed. Yes, I'd like to set a reminder on my phone to help me stay consistent and hopefully ease my mind more effectively.

It's great that you've identified your bedroom as the ideal spot for your daily mindfulness or journaling practice. Setting a reminder on your phone should also help you maintain consistency. I encourage you to give this new routine a try, and we can check in on your progress during our next session. Remember, small steps can lead to significant improvements over time.
I'll give this routine a real shot and hope it helps me quiet my racing thoughts about school and get more restful sleep. Thanks for the supportlooking forward to updating you next time.
